Hierarchical Model for Antibody Kinetics: Revisions Based on Advisor Feedback

Kwan Ho Lee

2025-04-15

Source: vignettes/Beamer_Antibody_Kinetics.qmd

Overview

  • Incorporates feedback from Dr.¬†Morrison
  • Aligns with Teunis et al.¬†(2016, 2023) formulations
  • Clarifies model parameter roles and their interpretation
  • Assumes block-diagonal covariance structure across biomarkers

Full Model Structure

Two-phase within-host antibody kinetics:

dydt={Œº1b(t),t<t1‚àíŒ±y(t)r,t‚â•t1with dbdt=Œº0b(t)‚àícy(t)b(t) \frac{dy}{dt} = \begin{cases} \mu_1 b(t), & t < t_1 \\ - \alpha y(t)^r, & t \ge t_1 \end{cases} \quad \text{with } \frac{db}{dt} = \mu_0 b(t) - c y(t) b(t)

Initial conditions: y(0)=y0y(0) = y_0, b(0)=b0b(0) = b_0
Key transition: t1t_1 is the time when b(t1)=0b(t_1) = 0
Derived quantity: y1=y(t1)y_1 = y(t_1)

Definition of Model Quantities

Parameters used in the dynamic model:

  • Œº0\mu_0: Pathogen growth rate
  • Œº1\mu_1: Antibody production rate (driven by pathogen)
  • cc: Clearance rate ‚Äî how effectively antibodies eliminate pathogen
  • Œ±\alpha: Antibody decay rate (governs speed of waning)
  • rr: Shape of antibody decay (nonlinear power)
  • y0y_0: Initial antibody concentration at t=0t = 0
  • b0b_0: Initial pathogen concentration at t=0t = 0
  • y1=y(t1)y_1 = y(t_1): Peak antibody level ‚Äî computed at time of pathogen clearance

Note: Only the first 7 are estimated. y1y_1 is derived from the ODE solution.

Model Comparison: 2016 vs Our Formulation

Component Teunis (2016) Our Model
Pathogen ODE Œº0b(t)‚àícy(t)\mu_0 b(t) - c y(t) Œº0b(t)‚àícy(t)b(t)\mu_0 b(t) - c y(t) b(t)
Antibody ODE (pre-t1t_1) Œºy(t)\mu y(t) Œº1b(t)\mu_1 b(t)
Antibody ODE (post-t1t_1) ‚àíŒ±y(t)r-\alpha y(t)^r Same
Antibody growth type Exponential Pathogen-driven
Antibody rate name Œº\mu Œº1\mu_1
t1t_1 formula Uses Œº\mu Uses Œº1\mu_1

Note:

  • Antibody production depends on pathogen presence (b(t)b(t)), not constant exponential growth
  • Pathogen clearance is proportional to both antibody and pathogen levels (cy(t)b(t)c\,y(t)\,b(t))

Hierarchical Priors ‚Äì Subject-Level and Means

Subject-level parameters:

ùõâij‚àºùí©(ùõçj,Œ£j),ùõâij=[y0,ijb0,ijŒº0,ijŒº1,ijcijŒ±ijrij] \boldsymbol{\theta}_{ij} \sim \mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{\mu}_j,\,\Sigma_j),\quad \boldsymbol{\theta}_{ij} = \begin{bmatrix} y_{0,ij} \\ b_{0,ij} \\ \mu_{0,ij} \\ \mu_{1,ij} \\ c_{ij} \\ \alpha_{ij} \\ r_{ij} \end{bmatrix}

Hyperparameters ‚Äì Means:

  • ùõçj\boldsymbol{\mu}_j: population-level mean vector for biomarker jj
  • Prior on ùõçj\boldsymbol{\mu}_j:

ùõçj‚àºùí©(ùõçhyp,j,Œ©hyp,j) \boldsymbol{\mu}_j \sim \mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\mathrm{hyp},j},\,\Omega_{\mathrm{hyp},j})

  • ùõçhyp,j\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\mathrm{hyp},j} and Œ©hyp,j\Omega_{\mathrm{hyp},j} are fixed or weakly informative

Clarifying Parameter Roles

Why the confusion about number of parameters?

  • The dynamic model contains 8 named parameters:

Œº0,Œº1,c,Œ±,r,y0,b0,y1 \mu_0, \mu_1, c, \alpha, r, y_0, b_0, y_1

  • But only 7 are estimated ‚Äî the 8th (y1y_1) is computed.
  • Let‚Äôs break this down carefully.

Classification of Parameters

Estimated Parameters (7 total):

  • Core model parameters (5):

Œº0,Œº1,c,Œ±,r \mu_0,\ \mu_1,\ c,\ \alpha,\ r

  • Initial conditions (2):

y0,b0 y_0,\ b_0

Derived Quantity (not estimated):

  • y1y_1: peak antibody level computed as y(t1)y(t_1)

Time of Pathogen Clearance: t1t_1

Definition: t1t_1 is the time at which the pathogen is cleared, i.e., b(t1)=0b(t_1) = 0

Analytic expression (Teunis et al., 2016):

t1=1Œº1‚àíŒº0log(1+(Œº1‚àíŒº0)b0cy0) t_1 = \frac{1}{\mu_1 - \mu_0} \log\left(1 + \frac{(\mu_1 - \mu_0)\,b_0}{c\,y_0} \right)

Key observations:

  • t1t_1 depends on Œº0\mu_0, Œº1\mu_1, b0b_0, y0y_0, and cc
  • Used to determine y1=y(t1)y_1 = y(t_1) by solving the antibody ODE up to this point
  • Not treated as an estimated parameter ‚Äî it is computed from model inputs

Why It‚Äôs a Seven-Parameter Model

  • Our model estimates 7 parameters:
    • 5 core biological parameters: Œº0,Œº1,c,Œ±,r\mu_0,\ \mu_1,\ c,\ \alpha,\ r
    • 2 initial conditions: y0,b0y_0,\ b_0
  • But we often talk about an eighth quantity, y1y_1, the highest level of antibody.
  • So why isn‚Äôt y1y_1 counted as a parameter?

Why y1y_1 Is Not Fit Directly

  • y1y_1 is the antibody level at the time the pathogen is cleared:

y1=y(t1)where b(t1)=0 y_1 = y(t_1) \quad \text{where } b(t_1) = 0

  • It is not an ‚Äúinput‚Äù to the model ‚Äî we don‚Äôt estimate it with MCMC.
  • Instead, we calculate it from the model:
    • We estimate parameters like Œº1\mu_1, y0y_0, b0b_0‚Ä¶
    • Then we solve the ODEs to find t1t_1 and compute y(t1)y(t_1)
  • In other words: y1y_1 is a derived output, not a parameter being fit.

How y1y_1 Is Computed

  • y1y_1 is computed by solving the coupled ODE system:

dydt=Œº1b(t),dbdt=Œº0b(t)‚àícy(t)b(t) \frac{dy}{dt} = \mu_1 b(t), \quad \frac{db}{dt} = \mu_0 b(t) - c y(t) b(t)

  • The solution is evaluated at t=t1t = t_1 (pathogen clearance point).
  • Therefore:

y1=y(t1;Œº1,y0,b0,Œº0,c) y_1 = y(t_1;\ \mu_1,\ y_0,\ b_0,\ \mu_0,\ c)

Recap: What We Estimate

Seven model parameters:

  • Œº0,Œº1,c,Œ±,r\mu_0,\ \mu_1,\ c,\ \alpha,\ r (biological process)
  • y0,b0y_0,\ b_0 (initial state)

Derived quantity:

  • y1=y(t1)y_1 = y(t_1), not directly estimated

Hierarchical Bayesian Structure

Individual parameters:

Œ∏ij=[y0,ijb0,ijŒº0,ijŒº1,ijcijŒ±ijrij]‚àºùí©(Œºj,Œ£j) \theta_{ij} = \begin{bmatrix} y_{0,ij} \\ b_{0,ij} \\ \mu_{0,ij} \\ \mu_{1,ij} \\ c_{ij} \\ \alpha_{ij} \\ r_{ij} \end{bmatrix} \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu_j, \Sigma_j)

Hyperparameters:

  • Œºj\mu_j: population-level means (per biomarker jj)
  • Œ£j\Sigma_j: 7√ó77 \times 7 covariance matrix over parameters

Subject-Level Parameters: ùõâij\boldsymbol{\theta}_{ij}

ùõâij‚àºùí©(ùõçj,Œ£j),ùõâij‚àà‚Ñù7 \boldsymbol{\theta}_{ij} \sim \mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{\mu}_j,\,\Sigma_j), \quad \boldsymbol{\theta}_{ij} \in \mathbb{R}^7

Where:

ùõâij=[y0,ijb0,ijŒº0,ijŒº1,ijcijŒ±ijrij],Œ£j‚àà‚Ñù7√ó7 \boldsymbol{\theta}_{ij} = \begin{bmatrix} y_{0,ij} \\ b_{0,ij} \\ \mu_{0,ij} \\ \mu_{1,ij} \\ c_{ij} \\ \alpha_{ij} \\ r_{ij} \end{bmatrix}, \quad \Sigma_j \in \mathbb{R}^{7 \times 7}

Each subject ii has a unique 7-parameter vector per biomarker jj, capturing individual-level variation in dynamics.

Hyperparameters: Priors on Population Means

Population-level means:

ùõçj‚àºùí©(ùõçhyp,j,Œ©hyp,j) \boldsymbol{\mu}_j \sim \mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\mathrm{hyp},j}, \Omega_{\mathrm{hyp},j})

Interpretation:

  • ùõçj\boldsymbol{\mu}_j: average parameter vector for biomarker jj
  • ùõçhyp,j\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\mathrm{hyp},j}: prior guess (e.g., vector of zeros)
  • Œ©hyp,j\Omega_{\mathrm{hyp},j}: covariance matrix encoding uncertainty

Example:

ùõçhyp,j=0,Œ©hyp,j=100‚ãÖI7 \boldsymbol{\mu}_{\mathrm{hyp},j} = 0, \quad \Omega_{\mathrm{hyp},j} = 100 \cdot I_7

Hyperparameters: Priors on Covariance

Covariance across parameters:

Œ£j‚àí1‚àºùí≤(Œ©j,ŒΩj) \Sigma_j^{-1} \sim \mathcal{W}(\Omega_j, \nu_j)

  • Œ£j\Sigma_j: variability/covariance in subject-level parameters
  • Œ©j\Omega_j: prior scale matrix
  • ŒΩj\nu_j: degrees of freedom

Example:

Œ©j=0.1‚ãÖI7,ŒΩj=8 \Omega_j = 0.1 \cdot I_7, \quad \nu_j = 8

Measurement Error and Precision Priors

Observed antibody levels:

log(yobs,ij)‚àºùí©(log(ypred,ij),œÑj‚àí1) \log(y_{\text{obs},ij}) \sim \mathcal{N}(\log(y_{\text{pred},ij}), \tau_j^{-1})

Precision prior:

œÑj‚àºGamma(aj,bj) \tau_j \sim \text{Gamma}(a_j, b_j)

  • œÑj\tau_j: shared measurement precision for biomarker jj
  • Gamma prior allows flexible noise modeling

Matrix Algebra Computation

Let K=7K = 7 (parameters), JJ biomarkers. Then:

Œòi=[Œ∏i1Œ∏i2‚ãØŒ∏iJ]‚àà‚ÑùK√óJ \Theta_i = \begin{bmatrix} \theta_{i1} & \theta_{i2} & \cdots & \theta_{iJ} \end{bmatrix} \in \mathbb{R}^{K \times J}

Assume:

vec(Œòi)‚àºùí©(vec(M),Œ£K‚äóIJ) \text{vec}(\Theta_i) \sim \mathcal{N}(\text{vec}(M), \Sigma_K \otimes I_J)

Matrix Algebra ‚Äì Simplified Structure

Setup: Œòi‚àà‚Ñù7√óJ\Theta_i \in \mathbb{R}^{7 \times J}

Model:

vec(Œòi)‚àºùí©(vec(M),Œ£K‚äóIJ) \text{vec}(\Theta_i) \sim \mathcal{N}(\text{vec}(M), \Sigma_K \otimes I_J)

  • Œ£K\Sigma_K: 7√ó7 covariance (same across biomarkers)
  • IJI_J: biomarkers assumed uncorrelated
  • Block-diagonal covariance

Understanding vec(Œòi)\text{vec}(\Theta_i)

Each Œ∏ij‚àà‚Ñù7\theta_{ij} \in \mathbb{R}^7:

Œ∏ij=[y0b0Œº0Œº1cŒ±r] \theta_{ij} = \begin{bmatrix} y_0 \\ b_0 \\ \mu_0 \\ \mu_1 \\ c \\ \alpha \\ r \end{bmatrix}

Flattening:

vec(Œòi)‚àà‚Ñù7J√ó1 \text{vec}(\Theta_i) \in \mathbb{R}^{7J \times 1}

Understanding vec(M)\text{vec}(M)

Let M=[Œº1Œº2‚ãØŒºJ]‚àà‚Ñù7√óJM = [\mu_1\, \mu_2\, \cdots\, \mu_J] \in \mathbb{R}^{7 \times J}

Example for J=3J=3:

M=[Œº1,1Œº1,2Œº1,3Œº2,1Œº2,2Œº2,3Œº3,1Œº3,2Œº3,3Œº4,1Œº4,2Œº4,3Œº5,1Œº5,2Œº5,3Œº6,1Œº6,2Œº6,3Œº7,1Œº7,2Œº7,3] M = \begin{bmatrix} \mu_{1,1} & \mu_{1,2} & \mu_{1,3} \\ \mu_{2,1} & \mu_{2,2} & \mu_{2,3} \\ \mu_{3,1} & \mu_{3,2} & \mu_{3,3} \\ \mu_{4,1} & \mu_{4,2} & \mu_{4,3} \\ \mu_{5,1} & \mu_{5,2} & \mu_{5,3} \\ \mu_{6,1} & \mu_{6,2} & \mu_{6,3} \\ \mu_{7,1} & \mu_{7,2} & \mu_{7,3} \end{bmatrix}

Covariance Structure: Œ£K‚äóIJ\Sigma_K \otimes I_J

Cov(vec(Œòi))=Œ£K‚äóIJ \text{Cov}(\text{vec}(\Theta_i)) = \Sigma_K \otimes I_J

  • Œ£K\Sigma_K: parameter covariance matrix
  • IJI_J: biomarker-wise independence
  • Kronecker product yields block-diagonal matrix

Example: Kronecker Product with K=2K=2, J=3J=3

Let:

Œ£K=[œÉ11œÉ12œÉ21œÉ22],I3=[100010001] \Sigma_K = \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_{11} & \sigma_{12} \\ \sigma_{21} & \sigma_{22} \end{bmatrix},\quad I_3 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}

Then:

Œ£K‚äóI3‚àà‚Ñù6√ó6 \Sigma_K \otimes I_3 \in \mathbb{R}^{6 \times 6}

Expanded Matrix: Œ£K‚äóI3\Sigma_K \otimes I_3

Œ£K‚äóI3=[œÉ1100œÉ12000œÉ1100œÉ12000œÉ1100œÉ12œÉ2100œÉ22000œÉ2100œÉ22000œÉ2100œÉ22] \Sigma_K \otimes I_3 = \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_{11} & 0 & 0 & \sigma_{12} & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & \sigma_{11} & 0 & 0 & \sigma_{12} & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & \sigma_{11} & 0 & 0 & \sigma_{12} \\ \sigma_{21} & 0 & 0 & \sigma_{22} & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & \sigma_{21} & 0 & 0 & \sigma_{22} & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & \sigma_{21} & 0 & 0 & \sigma_{22} \end{bmatrix}

Next Steps: Modeling Correlation Across Biomarkers

Current Limitation:

  • Biomarkers assumed independent: IJI_J

Planned Extension:

  • Use full covariance Œ£J\Sigma_J:

Cov(vec(Œòi))=Œ£K‚äóŒ£J \text{Cov}(\text{vec}(\Theta_i)) = \Sigma_K \otimes \Sigma_J

Extending to Correlated Biomarkers

Assume K=3K=3, J=3J=3

Define:

Œ£K=[œÉ11œÉ12œÉ13œÉ21œÉ22œÉ23œÉ31œÉ32œÉ33],Œ£J=[œÑ11œÑ12œÑ13œÑ21œÑ22œÑ23œÑ31œÑ32œÑ33] \Sigma_K = \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_{11} & \sigma_{12} & \sigma_{13} \\ \sigma_{21} & \sigma_{22} & \sigma_{23} \\ \sigma_{31} & \sigma_{32} & \sigma_{33} \end{bmatrix},\quad \Sigma_J = \begin{bmatrix} \tau_{11} & \tau_{12} & \tau_{13} \\ \tau_{21} & \tau_{22} & \tau_{23} \\ \tau_{31} & \tau_{32} & \tau_{33} \end{bmatrix}

Kronecker Product Structure: Œ£K‚äóŒ£J\Sigma_K \otimes \Sigma_J

Œ£K‚äóŒ£J=[œÉ11Œ£JœÉ12Œ£JœÉ13Œ£JœÉ21Œ£JœÉ22Œ£JœÉ23Œ£JœÉ31Œ£JœÉ32Œ£JœÉ33Œ£J] \Sigma_K \otimes \Sigma_J = \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_{11}\Sigma_J & \sigma_{12}\Sigma_J & \sigma_{13}\Sigma_J \\ \sigma_{21}\Sigma_J & \sigma_{22}\Sigma_J & \sigma_{23}\Sigma_J \\ \sigma_{31}\Sigma_J & \sigma_{32}\Sigma_J & \sigma_{33}\Sigma_J \end{bmatrix}

Now biomarkers and parameters can be correlated.

Expanded Form: Œ£K‚äóŒ£J\Sigma_K \otimes \Sigma_J (3x3)

The 9√ó99 \times 9 matrix contains all combinations œÉabœÑcd\sigma_{ab}\tau_{cd}

Not block-diagonal ‚Äî includes cross-biomarker correlation

Practical To-Do List (for Chapter 2)

Model Implementation:

  • Define full Œ£J\Sigma_J and prior: Œ£J‚àí1‚àºùí≤(Œ®,ŒΩ)\Sigma_J^{-1} \sim \mathcal{W}(\Psi, \nu)
  • Implement Œ£K‚äóŒ£J\Sigma_K \otimes \Sigma_J in JAGS

Simulation + Validation:

  • Simulate individuals with correlated biomarkers
  • Fit both block-diagonal and full-covariance models
  • Compare fit: DIC, WAIC, predictive checks
